results.title: Bill Onus hosting Alcheringa
results.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through Forgotten People(1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.title: The Family Law Production stills
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

results.title: Magnavox Odyssey console
results.material_description: Video game console functioning as a playable unit. Also includes original box with contents
results.brief_description: Modified Odyssey video game console with original packaging, original contents and two controllers
results.description:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972. Players controlled two dots while the console controlled another that darted around the screen and could be returned like the ball in pong. Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.
description_for_label:

Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.

results.title: Zvenigora (Musical Soundtrack)
results.brief_description:
Dovzhenko’s most audacious film combines ancient folklore with modern events in ranging over many centuries of Ukrainian history with a political aim of obliquely linking modern revolutionary Ukraine with its distant past. For Dovzhenko the fresco-like narrative was what he described as ‘a catalogue of my creative possibilities’. The four part structure with a strange quest for treasure at its centre, incorporates a series of bracketing devices to enclose such eccentric episodes as those involving a vampire-like monk, midsummer rituals on the river and a toytown battle. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Alexander Dovzhenko ; writer, Mikhail Johansen, Yuri Yurtik ; photography, Boris Zavelev.
Cast: Mikola Nademsky, Semyon Svashenko, Alexander Podorozhny.

results.title: Zvenigora
results.brief_description: Zvenigora is a complex yet compelling fantasy, presenting the story of a group of Russian peasants and their strong ties with the earth through a series of simple yet strikingly beautiful images. Spanning a period of a thousand years, the film relates the eternal struggle between needing to nurture the land and wanting to strip it of its treasures. A wealth of magical images fill and frame the landscape, from the wizard monk whose death-like countenance terrorises the invaders to the man who advertises his own suicide as theatrical entertainment then absconds with the box office takings. This film is as much a parable about human nature as it is a representation of the struggles of the Russian peasantry, using technical experiments similar to those of Georges Melies to embellish the transcendental nature of the subject. Zvenigora is the fourth film by Russian film master Alexander Dovzhenko, who began his career in film in 1926 after working as both a cartoonist and painter. Despite negative critical reaction to Zvenigora, it was the forerunner of his more celebrated films Arsenal (1929), Zemlya (1930), and Ivan (1932), which perpetuated his interest in honouring the lives and struggles of peasants, and served as a tribute to his heritage as a man of the Ukraine.

results.title: Zulu Zion
results.creator_credit: BBC, Peter Montagnon and Mischa Scorer
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this visit to South Africa Ronald Eyre looks at the ways Christianity has evolved into an almost completely different religion, with an emphasis on dreams, purification, healing and the power of the holy spirit. Black Africans separated from the land search to replace these roots in God and the three different Christian sects which are explored here - the Zionists, the Lutherans and the Nazarites, all in their different ways have combined traditional African religion with Christianity. A fascinating look at how two different religions can merge and evolve into something quite unique and alive.
